description: From Latin insessio, from insidere, insessum (“to sit in”). See insidious.

entries.meaning: The act of sitting, as in a tub or bath.
examples: 1601,  C[aius] Plinius Secundus [i.e., Pliny the Elder],  “”, in Philemon Holland, transl., The Historie of the VVorld. Commonly Called, The Natvrall Historie of C. Plinivs Secvndus. […], , London:  […]  Adam Islip, published 1635, →OCLC:Used by way of fomentation, insession, or bath.

entries.meaning: That in which one sits, as a bathing tub.
